children.text: Goal 1.1: Acquire Concepts About Print
Hold a book right side up and turn pages in the correct direction.
Track or follow print when listening to a familiar text being read.
Follow words from left to right and from top to bottom on the printed page.
Identify the difference between a letter, a word, and a sentence.
Show the one-to-one correspondence between a spoken word and a printed word.
Recognize the concept of letters, words, and sentences by segmenting spoken and print sentences into individual words.
Match oral words to printed words (e.g., pointing to print as one reads).
Locate information using alphabetical order to the first letter.
Identify purpose for print conventions such as end-sentence punctuation, paragraphing, bold print, and dialogue.
Locate information using alphabetical order to the second letter.
Use print conventions such as end-sentence punctuation, paragraphing, bold print, and dialogue. (698.05.c)
Locate information using alphabetical order past the second letter. (698.01.i)
Goal 1.2: Acquire Concepts About Text
Show that print represents spoken language and conveys meaning (e.g., his/her name, environmental print such as signs, school and classroom labels).
Name the parts of a book, including front cover, back cover, and title. (671.01.h)
Practice reading environmental print with assistance (e.g. signs, symbols). (680.05.b)
Locate and identify the title, author, and illustrator and table of contents of a book or reading selection. (680.04.a)
Read simple graphs, charts, and diagrams.
Identify different kinds of texts types.
Identify titles, tables of contents, and chapter headings to locate information.
Use information from simple graphs, charts and diagrams.
Identify text types and formats of various kinds of text.
Identify purpose for print conventions such as end-sentence punctuation, paragraphing, bold print, and dialogue.
Use graphics, graphs, tables, diagrams, parenthesis, italics and bold print to understand text. (698.05.b)
Apply knowledge of text types and formats of various kinds of text. (716.05.c)
Use text features (e.g., heading, captions) to comprehend various print formats (e.g., news papers, reference text).
Identify and use graphic features that support text meaning (e.g., diagrams, maps, charts, illustrations). (707.05.b)
Identify the structural features of popular media.
Explain text features that contribute to comprehension (e.g., headings, introductory and concluding paragraphs. (716.01.i)
Use the features of texts, such as formats, graphics diagrams, illustrations, charts, maps, and organization to find information and support understanding. (716.05.b; 716.05.c)
Apply the structural features of popular media.
Apply text features (e.g., directions, legend, index, and glossary, sequence, bold face print, headings) to explain text. (725.01.a)
Identify graphic sources of information (e.g., maps, graphs, illustrations, diagrams, timelines, or tables) to address research questions. (725.05.c)
Apply knowledge of organizational structures to understand information in text. (734.05.d)
Apply specific features of text to understand a selection including preface and appendix.
Interpret graphic features of text to clarify and extend meaning. (734.05.c)
Analyze the organizational structure of printed material and electronic sources to access information.
Analyze specific features of text, including the preface and appendix, to understand a selection.
Interpret graphic features of text to clarify and extend meaning.
Analyze the structure and format of various informational documents. (752.05.c)
Identify the text characteristics of different genres of literature. (752.02.a)
Analyze the structure and format of various informational documents. (752.05.c)
Identify the text characteristics of different genres of literature. (752.02.a)
Identify the features and the rhetorical devices of a variety of literature and informational documents. (752.01.b)
Identify the features and the rhetorical devices of a variety of literature and informational documents. (752.01.b)
Goal 1.3: Acquire Phonological Awareness Skills
Identify spoken words that rhyme (e.g., run, sun versus run, man). (671.01.b)
Orally produce rhyming words in response to spoken words (e.g., What rhymes with hat?). (671.01.b)
Orally produce groups of words that begin with the same initial sounds.
Blend spoken simple onsets and rimes to form real words (e.g., onset /c/ and rime /at/ makes cat).
Blend spoken phonemes (CVC) to form single syllable words (e.g., /d/…/o/…/g/… makes dog) and tell what word is made. (671.01.d)
Identify the initial and final sounds (not the letter) of a spoken word. (671.01.g)
Segment one-syllable words into its phonemes (e.g., using manipulatives to mark each phoneme).
Identify the number of syllables in a word.
Identify, first, middle, and last sound in a word.
Add, delete, or change initial sounds to make words. (680.01.j)
Blend two to four phonemes into recognizable words. (680.01.i)
Count the number of syllables in a spoken word.
Goal 1.4: Acquire Decoding Skills Using Word Parts
Match vowel and consonant sounds to appropriate letters. (671.01.f)
Match vowel and consonant sounds to all letters. (670.01.f)
Read abbreviations appropriate to grade level.
Use word patterns and/or word families to decode words in isolation and in context. (698.01.a)
Read abbreviations appropriate to grade level.
Use knowledge of vowel digraphs, diphthongs, and r-controlled letter-sound association to read new words. (689.01.d)
Read abbreviations appropriate to grade level.
Identify common root words, prefixes and suffixes, including Greek and Latin derivatives to decode unknown words. (707.01.e)
Read abbreviations appropriate to grade level.
Apply common root words, prefixes and suffixes, including Greek and Latin derivatives to decode words. (716.01.b)
Read abbreviations appropriate to grade level.
Apply common root words, prefixes and suffixes, including Greek and Latin derivatives to decode complex words. (725.01.a)
Read abbreviations appropriate to grade level.
Apply root words, prefixes and suffixes, including Greek and Latin derivatives to decode complex words. (734.01.a)
Read abbreviations appropriate to grade level.
Use structural analysis and apply root words, prefixes, and suffixes, including Greek and Latin derivatives, to decode complex words. (743.01.a)
Read abbreviations appropriate to grade level.
Goal 1.5: Acquire Decoding Skills Using Syllabication
Name upper and lowercase letters. (671.01.e)
Apply knowledge of common onsets, rimes and word patterns to decode and generate new words.
Identify chunks or small words to decode two and three syllable written words. (689.01.c)
Decode using syllable types and syllable patterns to decode words with 2-4 syllables. (698.01.a)
Use knowledge of syllable types and syllable patterns to decode multisyllabic words. (707.01.b)
Apply spelling and syllabication rules that aide in decoding and word recognition.
Apply spelling and syllabication rules to aid in decoding and word recognition.
Apply spelling and syllabication rules to decode unknown words.
Apply spelling and syllabication rules to decode unknown words. (743.01.a)
Goal 1.6: Acquire Decoding Skills Using Context
Use context clues and pictures to aid in decoding of new words.
Use context clues and pictures to aid in decoding of new words.
Use context clues to aid in decoding of new words. (698.01.e)
Use context clues to aid in decoding of new words. (707.01.f)
Use context clues to aid in decoding of new words.
Use context clues to aid in decoding of new words. (725.05.b)
Use context clues to aid in decoding of new words.
Use context clues to aid in decoding new words.
Goal 1.7: Acquire Fluency
Read at least 25 one-syllable high frequency words
Read at least 150 regular and irregular sight words fluently. (680.01.n)
Read aloud Grade 1 text fluently with at least 54 correct words per minute (see Idaho Reading Indicator fall to spring benchmarks).
Read at least 300 regular and irregular sight words fluently. (689.01f)
Read aloud Grade 2 text fluently with at least 94 correct words per minute (see Idaho Reading Indicator fall to spring benchmarks).
Fluently read at least 450 regular and irregular sight words.
Read aloud Grade 3 text fluently from at least 120 correct words per minute. (see Idaho Reading Indicator fall to spring benchmarks).
Read aloud grade-level-appropriate test with fluency and accuracy from at least 140 correct words per minute (Hasbrouck & Tindal).
Read grade-level-appropriate text with fluency and accuracy from at least 150 correct words per minute (Hasbrouck & Tindal).
Read grade-level-appropriate text orally with fluency and accuracy from at least 150 correct words per minute (Hasbrouck & Tindal).
Read grade-level- appropriate text with fluency and accuracy from at least 150 correct words per minute (Hasbrouck& Tindal).
Read grade-level-appropriate text with fluency and accuracy from at least 150 correct words per minute (Hasbrouck & Tindal).
Goal 1.8: Vocabulary and Concept Development
Classify common words in to basic categories.
Explain word meaning from the context in which the word is used (spoken or written).
Use words and concepts necessary for understanding math, science, social studies, and other Kindergarten content area text.
Identify the meaning of words by using common inflectional endings (e.g. s, ed, ing).
Identify common antonyms, synonyms, and homonyms.
Use words and concepts necessary for comprehending math, science, social studies, literature and other Grade 1 content area text.
Use personal and picture dictionaries to confirm and determine meanings of unfamiliar words.
Identify simple prefixes, and contractions suffixes to determine the meaning of unknown words. (689.01.e)
Identify common antonyms, synonyms, and homonyms to determine meaning of words.
Use words and concepts necessary for comprehending math, science, social studies, literature and other Grade 2 content area text.
Use a grade-level appropriate dictionary and glossary to define and confirm meaning of unknown words. (689.04.a)
Use knowledge of base words, common prefixes and suffixes to determine meaning of unknown words in isolation and in context. (698.01.i)
Identify synonyms, antonyms, homophones, and homographs to determine the meaning of words in context. (698.01.h)
Use words and concepts necessary for comprehending math, science, social studies, literature and other Grade 3 content area text.
Use a grade-level appropriate dictionary and glossary to define and confirm meaning of unknown words. (698.05.a)
Identify common root words, prefixes and suffixes, derived from Greek and Latin to determine the meaning of unknown words. (707.01.e)
Use context, synonyms, antonyms, homophones and homographs to develop an understanding of new words. (707.01.d)
Use words and concepts necessary for comprehending math, science, social studies, literature and other Grade 4 content area text.
Use a grade-level appropriate dictionary and glossary to define and confirm meaning of unknown words. (707.05.a)
Apply root words, prefixes and suffixes, derived from Greek and Latin to determine meaning of complex words (autograph, autobiography, biography, biology). (716.01.d)
Use context to identify the meaning of unfamiliar words and identify the intended meaning of words with multiple meanings. (716.01.d)
Use words and concepts necessary for comprehending math, science, social studies, literature and other Grade 5 content area text.
Use a grade-level appropriate dictionary, thesaurus, and, glossary to find or confirm word meanings. (716.05.a)
Infer word meaning from knowledge of root words, derived from Greek and Latin
Apply context to identify the meaning of unfamiliar words and identify the intended meaning of words with multiple meanings. (725.05.b)
Use words and concepts necessary for comprehending math, science, social studies, literature and other Grade 6 content area text.
6.LA.1.8.4	Use a grade-level appropriate dictionary, thesaurus, and glossary to find or confirm word meanings and/or clarify shades of meaning.
Apply origins of root words, prefixes and suffixes to determine the meaning of unknown words.
Explain relationships among words including connotation/denotation antonyms, synonyms, and words with multiple meanings.
Use prior knowledge, the text, context clues, and graphic features of text to predict, clarify, and/or expand word meanings and concepts. (734.01.b)
Clarify pronunciations, meanings, alternate word choices, parts of speech, and etymology of words using the dictionary, thesaurus, glossary and technology sources.
Apply origins of root words, prefixes, and suffixes to determine the meaning of unknown words.
Explain relationships among words including connotation/denotation, antonyms, synonyms, and words with multiple meanings.
Define words and concepts necessary for comprehending Grade 8 content area text.
Clarify pronunciations, meaning, alternate word choices, parts of speech and etymology of words using the dictionary, thesaurus, glossary, and technology resources.
Use knowledge of Greek and Latin roots, prefixes, and suffixes to analyze the origin and meaning of unknown words. (752.01.a)
Use context analysis to determine the meanings of unfamiliar words. (752.01.a)
Apply knowledge of roots and word parts to draw inferences about new words. (752.01.a)
Use context analysis to determine the meanings of unfamiliar words. (752.01.a)
Apply knowledge of roots and word parts to draw inferences about new words. (752.01.a)
Use context analysis to determine the meanings of unfamiliar and multiple-meaning words from American literature. (752.01.a)
Apply knowledge of roots and word parts to draw inferences about new words. (752.01.a)
Use context analysis to determine the meanings of unfamiliar and multiple-meaning words in literature representing various English speaking cultures and periods. (752.01.a)
Goal 2.1: Acquire Strategies and Skills for Comprehending Text
Tell the purpose for reading text.
Connect the information and events in texts to self.
Use picture clues and context to aid comprehension.
Tell the purpose for reading text.
Participate in connecting the information and events in texts to self and to the world.
Participate in drawing conclusions based on information gathered from pictures and print.
Tell the purpose for reading different kinds of text, including paragraphs. (689.02.a; 689.03.f)
Participate in connecting the information and events in texts to self, to the world, and to other texts.
Participate in drawing conclusions based on information gathered from pictures and print.
Tell the purpose for reading various kinds of text (e.g., textbooks, newspapers, instructional manuals, novels, essays).
Connect the information and events in texts to self, to the world, and to other texts.
Draw simple conclusions based on information gathered from text. (698.01.n)
State author's main purpose for writing various texts. (707.03.a)
Identify cause and effect relationships in text by responding to "why", "how", and "what if" questions.
Draw conclusions based on information gathered from text. (707.01.o)
State author's purpose for writing various texts.
Apply cause and effect relationships to gain meaning from text. (716.03.c)
Draw valid conclusions based on information gathered from text and cite evidence to support the conclusion. (716.03.c)
Determine the author's purpose, stated or implied, for writing various texts. (725.05.a)
Apply cause and effect relationships to gain meaning from text.
Make inferences, draw conclusions and form opinions based on information gathered from text and cite evidence to support.
Evaluate the purpose and use of various texts.
Distinguish cause and effect relationships in text to gain meaning.
Make inferences, draw conclusions and form opinions based on information gathered from text and cite evidence to support.
Determine the relationships among facts, ideas, and events used in various texts to support a central purpose. (743.04.c)
Distinguish cause and effect relationships in text to gain meaning.
Make inferences, draw conclusions, and form opinions based on information gathered from text and cite evidence to support.
Synthesize the content from several sources on a single issue; paraphrase ideas to demonstrate comprehension. (752.05.d; 752.05.e; 752.05.f)
Apply reading strategies to self monitor for comprehension.
Clarify an understanding of text by creating outlines, notes, annotations, charts, and/or diagrams.
Synthesize the content from several sources on a single issue; compare and contrast ideas to demonstrate comprehension. (752.02.c)
Apply reading strategies to self monitor for comprehension.
Clarify an understanding of text by creating outlines, notes, annotations, charts, and/or diagrams.
Compare and contrast similar themes or topics by authors from different time periods or cultures to explain how the historical or cultural context shapes each author's point of view.
Apply reading strategies to self monitor for comprehension.
Clarify an understanding of text by creating outlines, notes, annotations, charts, and/or diagrams.
Compare and contrast similar themes or topics by authors from different time periods or cultures to explain how the historical or cultural context shapes each author's point of view.
Apply reading strategies to self monitor for comprehension.
Clarify an understanding of text by creating outlines, notes, annotations, charts, and/or diagrams.
Goal 2.2: Acquire Skills to Comprehend Expository Text
Participate in identifying the topic of expository text that is heard or read.
Respond appropriately to questions based on fact in expository text, heard or read.
Identify and sequence information from expository text into correct order using pictures clues.
Follow two-or-three step directions using picture clues.
Participate in identifying the topic of expository text that is heard or read.
Answer questions (who, what, when, where, why, how) about expository text, heard or read. (680.01.p; 680.03.c; 680.03.d)
Identify facts and sequence important information from expository text into correct order using pictures clues.
Follow one-step written directions.
Identify the main idea, problem and solutions in expository text to support comprehension.
Answer questions (who, what, when, where, why, how) about expository text, heard or read. (689.03.d)
Identify facts and sequence important information from expository text into a logical order to retell facts.
Follow two-step written directions.
Identify cause-effect, compare-contrast, and descriptions that support comprehension.
Generate how, why, and what-if questions for interpreting expository texts. (698.04.b)
Identify facts and relevant details to sequence important information from expository text into a logical order to retell facts. (698.01.p)
Follow simple multi-step written directions.
Distinguish between facts and opinions in expository text to support comprehension.
Generate how, why, and what-if questions for interpreting expository texts
Identify main ideas and signal words to summarize information from expository text. (707.01.h)
Follow multi-step written directions.
Interpret details from a variety of expository texts to support comprehension.
Generate how, why, and what-if questions for interpreting expository texts
Apply central ideas and signal words to summarize information from expository text.
Follow multi-step written directions.
Apply knowledge of expository text structure to extend comprehension.
Generate how, why, and what-if questions for interpreting expository texts
Identify the facts and details that support the author's argument and summarize the findings.
Follow multi-step written directions.
Analyze expository text structure to extend comprehension.
Generate how, why, and what-if questions for interpreting expository texts.
Summarize the main idea (literal or inferential) and critical details of expository text. (734.01.h; 734.04.b; 734.04.c)
Follow multi-step written directions.
Evaluate expository text structure to extend comprehension.
Generate how, why, and what-if questions for interpreting expository texts
Apply central ideas (literal of inferential) and critical details to summarize information from expository text.
Identify the main purpose and anticipate outcomes of procedures specified in informational text.
Identify the thesis, evidence, and argument in informational texts (e.g., newspaper editorials and campaign speeches).
Define the purpose and audience of a variety of communication formats (e.g., essays, letters, user manuals, lab reports, websites). (752.05.c)
Evaluate an author's argument or defense of a claim by examining the relevance and comprehensiveness of evidence. (752.03.a)
Critique the logic of informational texts by examining the sequence of information and procedures. (752.05.a)
Define the purpose and audience of a variety of communication formats (e.g., essays, letters, user manuals, lab reports, websites). (752.02.a; 752.03.b)
Evaluate the comprehensiveness and validity of evidence in an author's argument. (752.03.a)
Analyze the relationships among theses and arguments in informational texts (e.g., newspaper editorials, promotional literature).
Define the purpose and audience of a variety of communication formats (e.g., essays, letters, user manuals, lab reports, websites). (752.05.a; 752.05.c)
Extend, through original analysis, arguments presented in primary and/or secondary sources. (752.03.e)
Analyze the relationships among theses and arguments to evaluate claims made in informational texts (e.g., policy statements, campaign speeches). (752.03.c)
Define the purpose and audience of a variety of communication formats (e.g., essays, letters, user manuals, lab reports, websites). (752.05.a; 752.05.c)
Extend, through original analysis, arguments presented in primary and/or secondary sources. (752.03.a)
Goal 2.3: Acquire Skills for Comprehending Literary Text
Explain why a story that is heard or read is real or imaginary.
Orally identify the characters in a story that is read aloud.
Orally identify the setting in a story read aloud.
Sequence and retell a story that is heard or read, into a beginning, middle and end. (671.03.a; 671.03.b)
Explain whether a literary selection, heard or read, is fiction or nonfiction. (680.03.a)
Orally identify and describe the characters in a story that is read aloud. (680.02.a)
Identify the setting in a story heard or read aloud.
Sequence and retell a story that is heard or read, into a beginning, middle and end. (680.03.b)
Identify differences in fiction or non fiction. (689.03.f)
Orally identify and describe the characters in a story that is read aloud. (689.03.b)
Identify the setting in a story heard or read aloud. (689.03.b)
Retell basic plots of literary text. (689.02.a)
Identify different genres of literature (e.g., fables, fairy tales, poetry, folktales). (698.02.a)
Describe characters (e.g., traits, roles, similarities/differences) within a literary selection, heard or read. (698.03.b)
Identify all aspects of the setting (e.g., time of day, place, year). (698.03.b)
Identify plots in literary text. (698.03.b)
Orally identify narrator (point of view) of a story.
Identify the lesson of a fable or folktale (theme).
Identify common idioms.
Identify defining characteristics of literature genres, including poetry. (707.02.a)
Describe characters (e.g., traits, roles, similarities/differences) within a literary selection, heard or read. (707.02.a)
Describe the setting and tell how it supports the story. (707.03.b)
Explain the main problem, conflict, and resolution of a story plot. (707.03.b)
Identify the narrator of a story (point of view).
Identify the moral of literary selection (e.g., fables, folktales, legends). .
Identify common similes and idioms
Identify various genres of fiction and kinds of poetry based on their characteristics. (716.02.a)
Analyze how a character's traits influence that character's actions. (716.03.b)
Describe the setting and tell how it supports the story. (716.03.b)
Analyze the main problem or conflict of a plot and explain how it was resolved. (716.03.b)
Identify the speaker of a story and recognize the difference between first-person and third-person. (716.03.b)
Identify the moral of literary selections (e.g., fables, folktales, legends).
Analyze metaphors and idioms to increase comprehension. (716.01.n)
Describe different genres of fiction and kinds of poetry, and the major characteristics of each form (725.02.a)
Distinguish between major characters and minor characters.
Analyze the influence of the setting on the problem and resolution of the story. (725.02.d)
Analyze the conflict of a plot and explain its resolution. (725.02.d)
Identify the literary point of view (e.g., first person, third person) in literary text.
Identify themes that appear in different literary works. (725.02.d)
Identify common literary devices (e.g., flashback, foreshadowing, personification) to increase comprehension. (725.01.g)
Read and respond to literature from a variety of genres, including poetry. (734.02.b)
Analyze characterization as shown through a character's thoughts, words, speech patterns, and actions; the narrator's description; and the thoughts, words, and actions of other characters. (734.02.d)
Explain the influence of setting on mood, character and plot of the story. (734.01.g; 734.02.d)
Analyze plot development, including types of conflict. (734.02.d)
Recognize points of view (e.g., first person, third person limited and omniscient). (734.02.d)
Analyze the themes of various genres. (734.02.d)
Identify literary devices (e.g., onomatopoeia, hyperbole, imagery) to increase comprehension. (734.01.g)
Orally respond to an author's style of writing.
Read and respond to literature from a variety of genres, including poetry. (743.02.a)
Interpret how situations, actions, and other characters influence a character's personality and development. (743.03.b)
Analyze the importance of the setting to the mood and to the meaning of the story. (743.03.b)
Evaluate the structural elements of the plot and how conflicts are addressed and resolved. (743.01.b; 743.03.b)
Explain the author's point of view and interpret how it influences the story. (743.03.a)
Analyze the themes across various genres.
Read and respond to literature from a variety of genres.
Determine characters' traits by what the characters say about themselves in narration, dialogue, and soliloquy. (752.03.b; 752.01.d)
Evaluate the importance of the setting to the mood and meaning of the text.
Explain the author's point of view and interpret how it influences the text.
Compare and contrast themes across works of prose, poetry, and drama.
Analyze significant literary devices including irony and symbolism. (752.01.g)
Compare and contrast authors' style on the basis of such elements as word choice and sentence complexity.
Read and respond to literature from a variety of genres.
Analyze characters' traits by what the characters say about themselves in narration, dialogue, and soliloquy. (752.03.b)
Explain the author's point of view and interpret how it influences the text.

Analyze recognized works of literature representing a variety of genres and traditions that: (752.02.c)
  • Trace the development of the major periods of American literature.
  • Contrast the major themes, styles, and trends in different periods.
  • Evaluate the influences (i.e., philosophical, political, religious, ethical, and social) of the historical period that shaped the characters, plot, and setting.
Analyze how voice and the choice of a narrator affect characterization.
Analyze the ways in which the theme represents a view or comment on life, using textual evidence to support the claim. (752.02)
Evaluate the significance of various literary devices, including irony, tone, and figurative language. (752.01.g; 752.02.d)
Evaluate the aesthetic qualities of style, including the impact of diction and figurative language, on tone, mood, and theme. (752.02.d)

Analyze recognized works of literature representing a variety of genres and traditions that: (752.02.a)
  • Trace the development of the major periods of British or World literature.
  • Contrast the major themes, styles, and trends in different periods.
  • Evaluate the influences (i.e., philosophical, political, religious, ethical, and social) of the historical period that shaped the characters, plot, and setting.
Evaluate how voice and the choice of a narrator affect characterization and the tone, plot, and credibility of a text. (752.02)
Evaluate the ways in which the theme represents a view or comment on life, using textual evidence to support the claim. (752.02)
Analyze the ways in which irony, tone, mood, symbolism, and the "sound" of language achieve specific rhetorical or aesthetic purposes. (752.02)
Evaluate the aesthetic qualities of style, including the impact of diction and figurative language, on tone, mood, and theme. (752.01.g; 752.02.d)

Listen and follow multiple-step oral directions.

Listen for answers to specific questions from information presented orally.

Listen to acquire and summarize information from a variety of sources. (709.01.c)

Listen to acquire and summarize information from a variety of sources.

Listen to acquire and summarize information from a variety of sources.

Stay on topic when speaking.
Retell stories or experiences that follow a logical sequence of events. (692.02.a)
Speak clearly at an appropriate pace for the type of communication (e.g., informal discussion, report to the class). (692.01.a)
Ask for clarification and explanation of stories and ideas
Paraphrase information that has been shared orally by others.
Organize simple oral presentations to maintain a clear focus. (701.01.a)
Retell stories or experiences, that follow a logical sequence of events.
Speak clearly at an appropriate pace for the type of communication (e.g., informal discussion, report to the class). (701.01.b)
Ask thoughtful questions and respond orally to relevant questions with appropriate elaboration.
Summarize major ideas and supporting evidence presented in oral presentations.
Organize oral presentations to maintain a clear focus. (710.01.b)
Deliver narrative (story) presentations that relate ideas, observations, or memories about and event or experience.
Engage the audience with appropriate words, facial expressions, and gestures. (710.01.a)
Ask questions that seek information not already discussed. (718.01.c; 719.03.c)
Deliver informative presentations about an important idea, issue, or event. (719.03.a)
Organize oral presentations to maintain a clear focus.
Deliver oral responses to literature that summarize important events and details. (719.02.a)
Use appropriate verbal and nonverbal techniques to maintain audience interest. (719.01.a; 719.01.b)
Ask questions to elicit information, including evidence to support a speaker's position.
Emphasize important points to assist the listener in following an oral presentation. (727.03.a)
Organize oral presentations to maintain a clear focus.
Deliver narrative presentations that include sensory details and establish a context, plot, and point of view. (727.02.a)
Use appropriate verbal and nonverbal techniques to maintain audience interest.
Deliver oral responses to literature that develop an interpretation that shows careful reading, understanding, and insight. (727.02.a)
Ask questions to elicit information, including evidence to support a speaker's position. (737.03.b)

Deliver informative presentations that: (737.02.a)
  • Organize and deliver relevant information about a focused topic.
  • Appeal to the background and interests of the audience.
  • Use a range of appropriate strategies to make the presentation engaging to the audience.
Organize oral presentations to maintain a clear focus.
Deliver narrative presentations that include sensory details and establish a context, plot, and point of view.
Use speaking techniques that include effective verbal and non-verbal communication. (737.01.a)

Deliver oral response to literature that: (737.02.a)
  • interpret a reading and provide insight.
  • Connect personal responses to the writer's techniques and to specific textual references.
Paraphrase a speaker's purpose and point of view and ask questions concerning the speaker's content, delivery, and attitude toward the subject.

Deliver oral summaries of articles that: (737.01.b)
  • Include the main ideas and the most significant details.
  • State ideas in own words, except for when quoted directly from sources.
Organize oral presentations to maintain a clear focus.

Deliver persuasive presentations that: (746.01.a)
  • Include a well-defined position on the topic.
  • Differentiate fact from opinion and support arguments with detailed evidence, examples, reasoning, and persuasive language.
Use speaking techniques that include effective verbal and non-verbal communication. (746.01.a)

Deliver oral response to literature that:
  • Interpret a reading and provide insight.
  • Connect personal responses to the writer's techniques and to specific textual references.
Choose appropriate techniques for developing the introduction and conclusion in a speech, including the use of literary quotations, anecdotes, and references to authoritative sources. (755.01.b)
Identify and use elements of classical speech forms (e.g., the introduction, transitions, body, conclusion) in formulating rational arguments and applying the art of persuasion and debate. (755.01.b)
Use props, visual aids, graphs, and electronic media to enhance the appeal and accuracy of presentations. (755.01.b)
Analyze the occasion and the interests of the audience and choose effective verbal and nonverbal techniques (e.g., voice, gestures, eye contact) for presentations. (755.01.c)
Use effective and interesting language, including formal expressions for effect, standard English for clarity, and technical language for specificity. (755.01.a)
Analyze historically significant speeches to find the rhetorical devices and features that make them memorable.
Deliver narrative presentations that narrate a sequence of events and communicate their significance to the audience. (755.01.b; 755.01.c)
Deliver expository presentations that provide evidence in support of a thesis. Include related claims and include information on all relevant perspectives. (755.01.b; 755.01.c)

Deliver oral responses to literature that advance a judgment and/or demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the significant ideas of a work or passage. Support important ideas and viewpoints through accurate and detailed references to the text and to other works. (755.02.a)

Deliver persuasive arguments (e.g., evaluation and analysis of problems and solutions, causes and effects) that structure ideas and arguments in a coherent, logical fashion. (755.01.a; 755.01.b; 755.01.c)
Deliver multimedia presentations that incorporate information from a wide range of media. (755.01.b)
Goal 6.3: Acquire Viewing Skills
Demonstrate awareness of different media. (675.01.a)
Demonstrate understanding of the main idea of media presentations. (675.01.b)
Participate in differentiating between real and imaginary in media presentations. (675.03.a)
Demonstrate awareness of different media.
Demonstrate understanding of the main idea of media presentations. (684.01.b)
Participate in differentiating between real and imaginary in media presentations. (684.03.a)
Demonstrate awareness of different media.
Determine main concepts and details from information viewed. (693.01.b)
Participate in differentiating between real and imaginary in media presentations. (693.03.a)
Identify grade-level-appropriate traditional and non-print media as sources of information. (702.01.a)
Identify the role of media in focusing people's attention on events and in forming their opinion on issues. (703.02.)
Identify the difference between fact and opinion in media presentations. (702.03.b)
Identify similarities and differences in a variety of viewed media. (711.01.a)
Demonstrate understanding of graphics, pictures, and charts appropriate to grade level.
Analyze the role of media in focusing people's attention on events and in forming their opinions on issues. (711.02.a)
Differentiate between fact and opinion in media presentations. (711.03.b)
View media as a source for information, entertainment, and persuasion. (720.02.a; 720.02.b)
Demonstrate understanding of graphics, pictures, and charts, appropriate to grade level.
Analyze the role of media in focusing people's attention on events and in forming their opinions on issues.
Analyze the purpose, organization, content, and delivery of verbal communication and non-verbal cues.
Use a variety of resources to produce visuals that communicate through print and non-print materials. (720.04.a; 720.04.b)
View media to analyze as source for information entertainment, and persuasion appropriate to grade level. (729.01.b)
Demonstrate understanding of graphics, pictures, and charts appropriate to grade level.
Analyze the role of media in focusing people's attention on events and in forming their opinions on issues.
Analyze the purpose, organization, content, and delivery of verbal communication and non-verbal cues.
Use a variety of resources to produce visuals in order to communicate to an audience. (729.04.b)
View media to analyze as source for information entertainment, and persuasion appropriate to grade level.
Demonstrate understanding of graphics, pictures, and charts appropriate to grade level. (738.01.a; 738.01.b)
Evaluate the role of media in focusing people's attention on events and in forming their opinions on issues.
Evaluate the purpose, organization, content, and delivery of verbal communication and non-verbal cues.
Apply technical skills to produce visuals that communicate to the audience. (737.04.b)
View media, appropriate to grade level, to analyze as source for information, entertainment, and persuasion.

Interpret, critique, and evaluate the various ways in which visual image makers (e.g., graphic artists, illustrators, and news photographers) communicate information and create impressions and opinions.
Evaluate the role of media in focusing people's attention on events and in forming their opinions on issues.
Evaluate the purpose, organization, content, and delivery of verbal communication and non-verbal cues.
Apply technical skills and a variety of resources to produce visuals that deliver information. (746.04.b)

Analyze strategies used by the media to inform, persuade, entertain, and transmit culture (e.g., advertising; stereotyping; visual representations, special effects, language). (755.01.b; 756.01.a; 756.02.a)
Analyze the impact of the media on the democratic process (e.g., exerting influence on elections, creating images of leaders, shaping attitudes) at the local, state, and national levels. (756.03.a)
Analyze the techniques used in media messages for a particular audience and evaluate their effectiveness. (756.03.a)
Compare and contrast the ways in which media genres (e.g., televised news, news magazines and documentaries, and online information) cover the same event. (756.02.a)
Identify the aesthetic appeal of a media presentation and evaluate the techniques used to create the effects. (756.02.a)
